fields.title: Declarations
fields.content:
The most basic form of a sentence in Japanese is to simply declare that **Something is another thing**. These sentences are formed with the following structure:↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_ は \_\_\_\_\_\_ です

The **topic particle** ** は** indicates the topic of the sentence that comes just before. **です** is a copula verb that means **"to be"** or **"is"**.↵↵Note: whilst **は** is ordinarily pronounced **ha**, when used as a particle it is pronounced **wa**

fields.title: Omission and Context
fields.content: In Japanese, **omission** and **context** are both very important. Often in Japanese, people will omit the subject of a sentence so the context of the conversation will imply meaning.↵↵Japanese **does not** have the **definite or indefinite articles** seen in english; a, an, the. Nor does japanese indicate plurality at the end of nouns like in english; tables, cars, etc. Like before, the context of the conversation and other aspects of the grammar indicate these things.↵↵One of the most common places to find omission is with the pronoun **you** / ** あなた**. Using **あなた** is often seen as rude so it is most often left out of speech and up to context

fields.title: Questions
fields.content:
In Japanese, a question is indicated by the particle **か** at the end of a sentence. This means that in order to turn a statement into a question, you simply have to add **か** to the end.↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_ か

↵↵↵↵↵↵As we learnt previously, the context of the conversation can change the meaning, so in the final example, the subject of the sentence changed do to the implication that the speaker wouldn\'t be asking their own age

fields.title: Possession
fields.content:
The concept of possession is indicated with the particle の when sandwiched between two **Nouns** as shown below:↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_　の　\_\_\_\_\_\_

↵↵

fields.title: More の
fields.content: The particle の is extreemly versitile and can used to pair two nouns together to give second noun the property of, or further description expressed in the first noun. の can also describe the origin of something.↵↵

fields.title: Sentence Structure
fields.content:
As you may have noticed in the past sections, the sentence structure in Japanese varies quite significantly from English. Whilst English typically follows the structure: **Subject** - **Verb** - **Object**.↵↵

I am a student

↵↵Japanese typically uses a **Subject/Topic** - **Object** - **Verb** structure.↵↵The particle **は** also indicates the **Subject** or **Topic** of the sentence by coming right after it.Whilst this will take some time to get used to so don\'t worry if it initially takes you some time to figure out what each sentence is saying!

fields.title: Counting
fields.content: Today we will be learning numbers and counting in Japanese. The following are the numbers up to ten:↵↵| Number | Translation |↵| --- | --- |↵| 1 | いち |↵| 2 | に |↵| 3 | さん |↵| 4 | よん OR し |↵| 5 | ご |↵| 6 | ろく |↵| 7 | なな OR しち |↵| 8 | はち |↵| 9 | きゅう |↵| 10 | じゅう |↵| 100| ひゃく |↵| 1,000 | せん |↵| 10,000 | まん |↵↵When Counting **above 10** Japanese follows a very logical structure using a composition of the numbers 1-10.↵↵Multiples of 10 (20, 30, 40 etc.) are expressed literally with a single digit number followed by the number **10**, **じゅう**, so **にじょう**, literally 2, 10, means 20. **ろくじょう**, literally 6, 10, is 60 etc. This same rule also applies for **multiples of 100** , **multiples of 1,000** and **multiples of 10,000**. With that in mind, **にひゃくろくじゅうなな** is **267**↵↵Fun Fact: The reason that the Japanese language has two words for 4 and 7 are because they are considered unlucky numbers. This is due to the fact that the traditional pronunciation (**し**) is similar to their verb to die **しぬ** In a similar vein, many tall buildings in Japan will not have a floor four, they will simply go from 3 to 5

fields.title: Thought that was too easy?
fields.content: Unfortunately, whilst counting is simple conceptually in Japanese, one important factor that often trips learners up is the pronunciation and spelling of the numbers as certain combinations of numbers cause the pronunciation to be modified. fields.title: Not!
fields.content:
So far we have only been able to declare or ask whether something is something else. Today we are going to look at negatives, i,e saying that something **isn\'t** another thing.↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_じゃありません

This is the negative tense of the copula verb **です**.↵↵As we will learn in more depth later, Japanese has many varying levels of formality. The more **casual** way to conjugate **です** into negative is: ↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_じゃない

fields.title: Not more!
fields.content:
Unfortunately that isn\'t quite the end of it for different way to say **not** in Japanese! It is important to note that the **じゃ** part of **じゃありません** and **じゃない** is actually a shortening of **では**↵↵This means that both of the ways we just learnt to express **not** can also be formed as the following↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ではありません

↵↵

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ではない

Using **では** can come across as a bit more formal or bookish, like saying **is not** over **isn\'t**.↵↵Note: as with the particle **は**, the **は** in **では** is pronounced **wa**.

fields.title: Hold up there's more...
fields.content: You might be thinking \'now I\'ve learnt to count I can count anything to my heart\'s content!\' If only that were the case. Unfortunatly in Japanese, when counting, you always have to use a counter to indicate the type of thing that you are counting, so whereas in English one would just say **\'Two cats\'** in Japanese you would have to add the counter word for small animals after the number. Think of this similar to how one would say \'Two **sheets** of paper\' or \'five **bottles** of beer\'. The main difference between this and Japanese counters being that the Japanese counters cannot be used as nouns on their own.

fields.title: Telling the Time
fields.content: Counting time in Japanese is similar to counting anything else, there are counters for both hour and minute.↵↵Using this we can say that **にじ** is **2:00** and **ろくじにじゅうななふん** is **6:27**↵↵As with all counting in Japanese however, there are some exceptions as some of the numbers and counters change when paired together.
